docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: • This individual datasheet was designed as one of four parts that will make up the final product in this EGR304 course. This GitHub contains most of the entire development process for this individual component.

docs.title: Project Summary
docs.text:
This project aims to assist in the separation and organization of trash in homes and selected locations. This individual design helps this project by processing the weight of the trash and transforming that value into a visual representation for the user.

team report.

docs.text: In this Team assignment, I designed the main section of the LED Scale subsystem involving the force sensor. To review the details about how this individual project works together with the other three projects go to "EGR 304 Team 207 Report"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This block diagram shows the first solid construction of the light sensor subsystem circuit. The diagram illustrates the microcontroller's connections to the sensor, the multiple outputs, and the communication between controllers and other team members via ribbon cables. The other components in the diagram are also visible. Although the system initially supplies 9 volts, this voltage passes through a regulator that distributes 5 functional volts to the system located within the dotted line. Arrows between connections indicate the flow of information and specify whether the signal is digital or analog, as well as the type of controller required for the inputs and outputs. The light sensor communicates with the op-amp, amplifying and inverting the received signal to meet the sensor's requirements before it is read by the microcontroller.

Capacitive Force Sensor 8 mm 100 N (22 lbs)$37.50/eachlink to product *Inexpensive* Fall within the weight limits* Connections are easy access * Requieres model specific addons* Brittle. * Option 2. * FSG005WNPB * $129.62/each * Link to product * Small in size * Low error percantage * Easy pin acces * More expensive * Small sensor base * Option 3. * FlexiForce A201 Sensor * $153.16/8pack * Link to product * Good weight tolerance * Great Temperature tolerance range * Lightweight * Only available in 8packs * Hard pin access

Choice: Option 1: Capacitive Force Sensor 8 mm 100 N (22 lbs)

Rationale: Our choice 1 (Capacitive Force Sensor) is the option chosen for three different reasons: price, style, and versatility. This option has the best price of the three, as one can only be purchased in packs of 8, and the other is quite expensive due to its precision and size. Second, the pin selection is exposed and easily accessible for soldering. In turn, its light weight and design are quite helpful for the model we want to produce, where the basket rests on the base of the sensor.

Rationale: Our choice is option 3, since despite having previous experience with it, it also offers a greater number of circuits to assign in each respective system.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This schematic shows the complete circuit design for the light sensor subsystem. Figure 01 shows the nine sections that make up the light sensor subsystem. These are: the Curiosity Nano in the center, the light sensor in the horizontal rectangle in the upper left corner, the voltage regulator in the upper rectangle, the power supply for the Curiosity Nano in the rectangle to its right, the LED scale on the far right, the debugging push button in the lower right corner, the test LED to the left of the debugging button, and the ribbon cables below the Curiosity Nano.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This zip file contains all the files generated by MPLabX when packaging the project, including Demo_This_Better_Work_GC.zip, which contains the main.c file that runs the code on the microcontroller. This code processes the signal sent by the light sensor, amplified by the op-amp, and converts the reading to values ​​that the microcontroller can read, turning on the corresponding LED. The controller also receives information from the proximity subsystem, overwriting the light sensor code. The microcontroller also sends information to the speaker subsystem if the established light limits are reached.

The Code files for the Microcontroller are available here
